38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894723031479"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kg005" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="k0005" class="keyword"><span>N/O co-doping</span></div><div id="k0010" class="keyword"><span>Enlarged carbon interlayer distance</span></div><div id="k0015" class="keyword"><span>Durability</span></div><div id="k0020" class="keyword"><span>Hard carbon</span></div><div id="k0025" class="keyword"><span>Sodium-ion batteries</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="s0005"><h2 id="st030" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0035"><span><span>Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) have been widely studied due to their suitable <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/oxidation-reduction-potential" title="Learn more about redox potential from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox potential</a>, low cost, and abundant </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> resource </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0005" name="bb0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0010" name="bb0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0015" name="bb0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0020" name="bb0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0025" name="bb0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0030" name="bb0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>. Nevertheless, the larger ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup> (1.02&nbsp;Ã…) compared with Li<sup>+</sup> (0.76&nbsp;Ã…) results in sluggish diffusion kinetics, which severely hampers the development of Na insertion materials, especially anodes for SIBs <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0035" name="bb0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[7]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0040" name="bb0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0045" name="bb0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0050" name="bb0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0055" name="bb0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a><span>. Therefore, various <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a> based on different reaction mechanisms including intercalation, alloy, and conversion have been widely investigated </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0060" name="bb0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0065" name="bb0065" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0065"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0070" name="bb0070" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0070"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[14]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0075" name="bb0075" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0075"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[15]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0080" name="bb0080" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0080"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0085" name="bb0085" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0085"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0090" name="bb0090" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0090"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>. Generally, anode materials operated on the alloy and conversion types exhibit high theoretical capacity, whereas are accompanied by inferior cyclability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0095" name="bb0095" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0095"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[19]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0100" name="bb0100" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0100"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[20]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0105" name="bb0105" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0105"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[21]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0110" name="bb0110" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0110"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[22]</span></span></a>. Excellent reaction reversibility and modest reversible capacity provide broad application prospects for the anode materials based on intercalation reaction <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0115" name="bb0115" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0115"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[23]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0120" name="bb0120" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0120"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[24]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0125" name="bb0125" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0125"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[25]</span></span></a><span>. Among them, hard carbons (HCs), with abundant graphitic domains, pores, and defects, exhibit superb <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performances from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performances</a> and have been used for practical applications </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0130" name="bb0130" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0130"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[26]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0135" name="bb0135" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0135"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[27]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0140" name="bb0140" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0140"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[28]</span></span></a>. However, low Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics in HCs hinders the fast charge/discharge performance, resulting in poor rate capability and insufficient cyclic stability, which greatly restricts their development <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0145" name="bb0145" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0145"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[29]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0150" name="bb0150" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0150"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[30]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0155" name="bb0155" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0155"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[31]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0160" name="bb0160" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0160"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[32]</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Substantial efforts have been paid to address the above-mentioned issues for HC anodes. Based on the Na<sup>+</sup> storage behavior in HC material, the modification strategies could be classified into three types: i) increasing the carbon interlayer distance to facilitate the repeated (de)intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0170" name="bb0170" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0170"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a><span><span>. Xu and co-workers reported that the edge-nitrogen enriched <a href="/topics/materials-science/porous-carbon" title="Learn more about porous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous carbon</a> </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanosheet" title="Learn more about nanosheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanosheets</a> delivered a highly reversible capacity of 294.1&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>. ii) introducing heteroatoms, defects, and active sites into the carbon skeleton to enhance reaction kinetics and cyclic stability <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0185" name="bb0185" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0185"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[37]</span></span></a><span>. Huang and co-workers reported that the N-doped three-dimensional (3D) mesoporous carbon <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanosheet" title="Learn more about nanosheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanosheets</a> delivered a high reversible capacity of 239.3&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 10,000 cycles <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0190" name="bb0190" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0190"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[38]</span></span></a>. iii) designing nanoarchitecture of HC to shorten the diffusion length and enrich the diffusion channel for both ions/electrons <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0195" name="bb0195" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0195"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0200" name="bb0200" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0200"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a><span>. Guo and co-workers reported that the 3D porous carbon consisted of cross-linking <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanosheet" title="Learn more about nanosheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanosheets</a> delivered optimized rate performance (66.9&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 9.6&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0205" name="bb0205" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0205"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a><span>. Therefore, it deserves expected that sodium storage performance in the HC anode could be improved by integrating the above-mentioned strategies. Nevertheless, modified HC anodes with all the above key indicators (expanded interlayer, <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/heteroatom-doping" title="Learn more about heteroatom doping from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heteroatom doping</a>, and hierarchical structure) are difficult to be achieved by a facile synthetic method.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045"><span><span>In this study, we fabricated 3D N/O co-doped HCs (NOHCs) with high rate performance and ultralong cycle life as the anode for SIBs through a mild strategy. The unique porous <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/nanostructure" title="Learn more about nanostructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructure</a><span> has consisted of ultrathin graphene-like nanosheets in three dimensions. Such hierarchical <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanostructure" title="Learn more about nanostructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructure</a> exposes an enlarged active surface and increased </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> of electrolyte, which expedite both electron transportation and ion diffusion. Additionally, the abundant active sites contributed by porosity design and N/O co-doping could also boost surface-dominated Na-storage. Meanwhile, the expanded interlayer in NOHCs can lower the barrier for Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> insertion/extraction and thus improve the ion diffusion kinetics. As the anode for SIBs, the optimized NOHC-2 electrode with hierarchical <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structure</a> expanded interlayer, and abundant active sites, exhibits promising sodium storage performances. Furthermore, the full cell assembled by NOHC-2 anode and Prussian blue (PB) cathode exhibits a high energy density/power density and excellent stability in well-known previous reports.</span></div></section><section id="s0010"><h2 id="st035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Results and discussion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0050"><span>NOHCs sample were obtained by the <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a> of poly (aniline-co-pyrrole) and NaCl at 900&nbsp;Â°C, 1000&nbsp;Â°C, and 1100&nbsp;Â°C, denoted as NOHC-1, NOHC-2, and NOHC-3, respectively. As could be observed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>aâ€“c, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the as-synthesized NOHCs exhibit ultrathin graphene-like <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/nanosheet" title="Learn more about nanosheets from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanosheets</a><span> with a honeycomb morphology. The microstructure of NOHCs is detected by the <a href="/topics/materials-science/transmission-electron-microscopy" title="Learn more about transmission electron microscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">transmission electron microscopy</a> (TEM) technique (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a><span>aâ€“c), which displayed <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/hierarchical-porous" title="Learn more about hierarchical porous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hierarchical porous</a><span> structures. The molten NaCl salt utilized in heat treatment could not only facilitate the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/graphitization" title="Learn more about graphitization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization</a> degree of the as-derived carbon but also acted as a template to introduce macropores </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0210" name="bb0210" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0210"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>. The abundant porous structure provides a large amount of ion transport channels and mitigates the volume change of NOHCs. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span>dâ€“f, high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images of all the samples manifest a typical short-range ordered <a href="/topics/materials-science/crystal-microstructure" title="Learn more about crystal microstructure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystal microstructure</a><span>, wherein the gradual growth of <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis</a> temperature indicates the effectively elevated graphitization. The NOHC-2 presents scattered and highly disordered graphitic layers with large interlayer spacings, generally over 0.40&nbsp;nm. In contrast, NOHC-1 and NOHC-3 samples have smaller interlayer distances, unexceptionally larger than that of graphite, implying the facilitated Na</span></span><sup>+</sup> diffusion dynamics. The change of carbon layer distance herein could be affected by the annealing temperature as well as the degree and types of heteroatoms (N, O) doping <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0175" name="bb0175" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0175"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0215" name="bb0215" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0215"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[43]</span></span></a>, which will be discussed in the following context. According to <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0005" name="bf0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>g and S1d, e, the NOHCs are composed of C, N, and O elements, in which the C element is dominated.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr1.jpg" height="685" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0005"><p id="sp0020"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Morphology characterizations of NOHCs: (a-c) SEM images; (d-f) HRTEM observations; (g) <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDS</a> mapping images for NOHC-2.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0055">To investigate the crystallographic structure of as-prepared NOHCs materials, powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were collected and shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a. All the samples display two broad peaks at&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;23Â° and&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;42Â°, corresponding to the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;2) and (1&nbsp;0&nbsp;0) diffraction lines of graphite planes, respectively. Compared to the (0&nbsp;0&nbsp;2) peak in pure graphite at&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;26.6Â°, it shifts to a lower diffraction angle in NOHCs, indicating enlarged lattice spacing, which agrees well with the HRTEM results <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0165" name="bb0165" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0165"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a><span>. The elevated <a href="/topics/materials-science/lattice-constant" title="Learn more about lattice parameters from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lattice parameters</a> might be attributed to heteroatom (N, O) doping, which induces the distortion of the hexagonal carbon skeleton. Raman spectra were carried out and the results were demonstrated in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>b, wherein the prominent peaks at&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;1335&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;1588&nbsp;cm<sup>âˆ’1</sup> could be assigned to the signals of disordered carbon (D band) and graphitic carbon (G band), respectively. The decreased I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub><span> values with temperature elevation confirm the enhanced graphitization and mitigated defects. Nitrogen physisorption-absorption isotherms were conducted to further investigate the specific surface area and <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structure</a>. Unambiguously, typical IV-type isotherms with an H3 hysteresis loop are observed in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>c, implying the existence of microporous and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a> in the as-prepared materials. The surface areas are determined to be 301.5, 320.2, and 393.3&nbsp;m</span><sup>2</sup> g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for NOHC-1, NOHC-2, and NOHC-3, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>). Remarkably, the specific surface area of NOHCs fluctuates with the rise of temperature, which is consistent with the previous literature reports <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a><span>. Meanwhile, by analyzing the <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>d), it can be seen the obvious mesopores response in NOHC-2, and NOHC-3 is around 2.0&nbsp;nm, which could be attributed to surface â€œcavityâ€ defect sites. Particularly, hierarchical porous structure for NOHC-2 and NOHC-3 anodes could provide abundant active sites and be served as Na<sup>+</sup> buffering reservoirs, thus effectively enhancing ion diffusion kinetics.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0010"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr2.jpg" height="519" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (678KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (678KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0010"><p id="sp0025"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>Spectroscopic characterizations for NOHCs: (a) <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffraction-pattern" title="Learn more about XRD patterns from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD patterns</a>; (b) </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a><span><span>; (c) Nitrogen adsorptionâ€“desorption isotherms; (d) <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about Pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Pore size distribution</a>; (e) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> survey spectra; (f) Element content of C, O, and N. High-resolution XPS spectra of NOHC-2: (g) C 1&nbsp;s, (h) N 1&nbsp;s and (i) O 1&nbsp;s.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">To elucidate the elemental composition and bonding configuration of NOHCs, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) characterization was performed and shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e. The NOHCs materials are found mainly composed of C, N, and O elements, and quantitative analysis (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>f) exhibits that the amount of N and O decreases with elevated annealing temperature, manifesting the lowest defect and doping content in the NOHC-3 sample. The quantitative analysis of elements can also be demonstrated by <a href="/topics/materials-science/elemental-analysis" title="Learn more about elemental analysis from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">elemental analysis</a> (EA) tests (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a>). Representatively, the narrow spectra of C 1&nbsp;s, N 1&nbsp;s, and O 1&nbsp;s for NOHC-2 material are comprehensively investigated and displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g-i. In the C 1&nbsp;s XPS profile, the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C (âˆ¼284.8&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">N (âˆ¼285.4&nbsp;eV), C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O (âˆ¼286.8&nbsp;eV), and O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O (âˆ¼289.8&nbsp;eV) bonds can be detected (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g). The high resolution XPS spectrum of N 1&nbsp;s for NOHC-2 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>h) could be fitted into three peaks: pyridinic nitrogen (N-6, 398.2&nbsp;eV), pyrrolic nitrogen (N-5, 398.9&nbsp;eV), and quaternary nitrogen (N-Q, 401.6&nbsp;eV). As functional groups for the electrochemically active sites, N-6 and N-5 can enhance the surface-induced capacity and improve the diffusion kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0220" name="bb0220" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0220"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>. Previous studies have shown that a lone pair of electrons retained in N-5, which are vertical to the graphite carbon layer, can effectively increase the graphitic spacing <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0225" name="bb0225" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0225"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>. It should be noted that the carbon interlayer distance of NOHCs is positively correlated with the N-5 percentage, indicating that the largest carbon interlayer spacing of NOHC-2 is ascribed to its highest N-5 doping ratio (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S3</span></span></a>). Moreover, N-Q is embedded in the graphene plane and bonded with three <em>sp<sup>2</sup></em><span> carbon atoms, which is conducive due to the significant change in the electron-donor characteristic. This result again confirms the effect of heteroatomic doping, consistent with the results from <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> and HRTEM analysis. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0010" name="bf0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>i, two typical peaks at 531.4 and 532.7&nbsp;eV are observed in the O 1&nbsp;s spectrum, corresponding to C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"><span>O groups, respectively. Importantly, the presence of O-doping can provide more active sites and improve the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a> between the electrolyte and electrode surface, leading to better reaction kinetics. The chemical bonding states of NOHC-1 and NOHC-3 exhibit little difference from NOHC-2 (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a>). And the specific degree and types of N/O-doping are summarized in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S2</span></span></a><span>. Furthermore, the C&nbsp;=&nbsp;O and C-N sites are further demonstrated by <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/ftir-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy</a> (FTIR) as shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0065"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a shows the cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves of the Na//NOHC-2 half-cell in the voltage range of 0.01&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;3.0&nbsp;V with a scanning rate of 0.1&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>. Two obvious cathodic peaks emerge at&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;0.05&nbsp;V and 0.4&nbsp;V during the first discharge process while weakening in the following cycles, implying the decomposition of the electrolyte and the formation of the <a href="/topics/materials-science/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a> interphase (SEI) layer. The redox peaks at a low voltage range of 0.01â€“0.20&nbsp;V can be observed and well-maintained in the following cycles, which could be attributed to the insertion/extraction of Na</span><sup>+</sup> into/from graphitic layers and micropores in the NOHC-2. The curves of the subsequent cycles are almost overlapped, implying the highly reversible reaction upon cycling. The curves of NOHC-1 and NOHC-3 exhibit a similar shape to that of NOHC-2, confirming the similar reaction process of Na<sup>+</sup> storage (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a>a, b). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b shows the highest reversible capacity (324.3&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) of NOHC-2 at a current density of 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which could be ascribed to its abundant active sites, as will be discussed in the following context. As illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a><span>c, d, the discharge/charge profiles of NOHC-2, which present two potential plateaus corresponding to the CV curves, remain almost unchanged even after 300 cycles, exhibiting superior <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/structural-stability" title="Learn more about structural stability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">structural stability</a><span>. Such low and stable voltage plateaus of NOHC-2 are advantageous in increasing <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/flux-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> for SIBs towards practical applications. The rate performances of NOHCs were investigated under different current densities (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>). Remarkably, NOHC-2 delivers an excellent reversible capacity of 169.8&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at the current density of 5.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. Even after a high current density of 10.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the discharge capacity of NOHC-2 can be recovered to 324.3&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. The superior rate performance of NOHC-2 roots in its well-developed hierarchical structure, large graphitic layer spacing, and modest N/O doping contents generate a rich reaction surface with abundant active sites between electrolyte and electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a>). Compared to some recently reported typical carbon anodes for SIBs, the NOHC-2 presents obvious superiority in high-rate performance (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S4</span></span></a>). The charge/discharge cycle tests of NOHC-2 reveal a stable reversible capacity of 225.4&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at the current density of 1.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, long cycle stability of 1000 cycles with negligible degradation (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>). Even after 15,000 cycles at the current density of 10.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the reversible capacity is still maintained at&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;160&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which is 69.8% of the second cycle (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f). Overall, the ultralong cyclic stability of NOHC-2 further confirms the robust structural stability upon repeated cycling.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0015"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr3.jpg" height="564" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (721KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (721KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0015"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. <span><span><a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-property" title="Learn more about Electrochemical properties from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electrochemical properties</a> of NOHCs anodes in the NOHCs//Na half cells: (a) </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves at different scan rates; (b) Long-term cycle stability of NOHCs at the current density of 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>; (c) Charge/discharge curves of NOHC-2 at various cycles; (d) Rate capability of NOHC-2; (e) Comparison of the reversible capacity of NOHC-2 and reported representative carbon materials; (f) Long-term cycling stability of NOHC-2.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0070">To investigate the mechanism of high-rate performance of the NOHC-2 anode, CV curves at different sweep rates of 0.1&nbsp;âˆ¼&nbsp;5.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> were studied (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>aâ€“c, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>). The profiles of CV curves are gradually expanded with the increase of scan rate, reflecting the existence of various reaction processes, such as diffusion-controlled and capacitive-controlled. The equation of <em>i</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>av<sup>b</sup></em> is used to calculate the dominating-controlled process, wherein <em>v</em> represents the sweep rate, <em>i</em> indicates the response current, <em>a</em> and <em>b</em> are adjustable parameters <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0230" name="bb0230" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0230"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>. Theoretically, <em>b</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;1 means that the electrochemical process is controlled by the capacitive process, and <em>b</em>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.5 implies that the electrochemical process is diffusion-controlled. When the <em>b</em><span> value is between 1 and 0.5, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electrochemical-reaction" title="Learn more about electrochemical reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical reaction</a> is affected by the capacitive and diffusion-controlled processes. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a>gâ€“i, the <em>b</em> value of NOHC-2 at the cathodic peak is higher than those for both NOHC-3 and NOHC-1, implying that the capacitive-controlled process is more dominant in NOHC-2 than the other two electrodes. This is key to achieving excellent high-rate performance and cycling stability at high current density. The ratio of capacitive contribution can be quantitatively calculated using the equation of <em>i</em>(<em>V</em>)&nbsp;=&nbsp;<em>k<sub>1</sub></em>&nbsp;+&nbsp;<em>k<sub>2</sub>v<sup>1/2</sup></em>, which was proposed by Dunn and Chao <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0235" name="bb0235" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0235"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>. The CV curve at a certain sweep rate (5.0&nbsp;mV&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) is fitted, and the shadow area relates to the capacitive contribution with a ratio of 93.4% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>b).</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0020"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr4.jpg" height="619" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (865KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (865KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0020"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. <span>Electrode analysis upon cycling process: (a) <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> curves of NOHC-2; (b) Contribution of the capacitive and diffusion process of NOHC-2; (c) Capacitive contribution ratio of NOHC-2 at different scan rates; (d) GITT curves of the as-prepared NOHCs; The Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/diffusivity" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of the as-prepared NOHCs through GITT treatment: during (e) discharging and (f) charging processes; </span><em>Ex-situ</em><span> <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> profiles of NOHC-2 at different potentials during the second lap charge/discharge processes: (g) O 1&nbsp;s and (h) Na 1&nbsp;s; (i) Selective </span><em>In-situ</em><span><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/raman-spectra" title="Learn more about Raman spectra from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Raman spectra</a> for NOHC-2 anode (including the corresponding charge/discharge curve in </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>, the relative Raman shift of G peak, and the variation of I</span><sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> value with the voltage).</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">Furthermore, with the increase of sweep speed, the ratio of capacitive contribution increases gradually and finally reaches 93.4% (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span><span>c). The highest proportion of capacitive behavior for the NOHC-2 could be attributed to modest defects arising from the intrinsic <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> nature and modest N/O dual-doping. GITT tests were applied to further investigate the </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of Na</span><sup>+</sup> in NOHCs. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>dâ€“f, Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanisms in NOHCs can be divided into three aspects: trace adsorption derived from the electrode surface at the high-potential slope (Stage â… , double-layer capacitance reactions, &gt;1.0&nbsp;V), the surface-dominated Na<sup>+</sup> from the reversible adsorption/desorption on the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O sites at high-potential plateau (Stage II, the capacitive capacity contributed by the oxygen-containing group for NOHCs, 0.1â€“1.0&nbsp;V), and the Na<sup>+</sup> (de)intercalation into the graphitic layers and micropores filling in Na metal clusters at low-potential plateau (Stage III, 0.01â€“0.1&nbsp;V), respectively <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0240" name="bb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0245" name="bb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>. The diffusion coefficients of NOHC-2 are generally higher than those of NOHC-3 and NOHC-1 during discharging/charging process, representing faster Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion in NOHC-2 and excellent rate performance.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080"><em>Ex-situ</em><span> XPS profiles of NOHC-2 were applied to explore the chemical composition at different chargeâ€“discharge voltages. To exclude the influence of other factors, the materials for tests were cleaned using Dimethoxyethane and protected under an Ar atmosphere throughout the whole process. Compared to the full XPS spectra, the Na 1&nbsp;s peak of exhibits obvious change of content at different charge/discharge states, indicating the reversibly reaction of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage in the NOHC-2 (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>). In the O 1&nbsp;s XPS spectra (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g), the peak intensity of the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O band at 531.1&nbsp;eV gradually weakens, while two new peaks of C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Na (531.9&nbsp;eV) and Na KLL Auger appear and increase gradually during the discharge to 0.01&nbsp;V <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0250" name="bb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0255" name="bb0255" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0255"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>. In the following charge process, the peak intensities of C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Na and Na KLL Auger gradually mitigate, indicating the excellent reversibility of the Na<sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a>. This result demonstrates that Na</span><sup>+</sup> could reversibly react with the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O groups as described by C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O&nbsp;+&nbsp;Na<sup>+</sup>&nbsp;+&nbsp;e<sup>âˆ’</sup>&nbsp;â†”&nbsp;<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Na, which explains the obvious plateau (âˆ¼0.5&nbsp;V) in the discharge curve of NOHC-2 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0015" name="bf0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>c), contributing to the highest reversible capacity among the as-prepared NOHCs materials. When charged to 3.0&nbsp;V, the peak of Na KLL Auger could also be observed, indicating a certain amount of residual metallic sodium. Additionally, the analysis in the area proportion of C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Na/metallic Na in the Na 1&nbsp;s spectra during a full discharge/charge process further confirms the sodium storage behavior due to the interaction between Na<sup>+</sup> and C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O groups (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>h, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a>). Similar to the GITT analysis, the active sites (mainly for C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O) are positive to the reversible adsorption/desorption capacity, conducing to the rapid adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> (Stage II), and the Na<sup>+</sup> (de)intercalation into the graphitic layers and micropores filling in Na metal clusters at low-potential plateau (Stage III).</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0085"><em>In-situ</em> Raman spectrum was measured to further study the sodium storage behavior in the NOHC-2 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0020" name="bf0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>i). As shown in the discharge/charge profile, the main capacity contribution comes from 0.01&nbsp;âˆ’&nbsp;1.0&nbsp;V, corresponding to Stage II and Stage III. The ratio of I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> continues to decrease during the sodiation process, suggesting the decreased asymmetry of heterocyclic rings along with the interaction of Na<sup>+</sup> with N/O atoms <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0260" name="bb0260" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0260"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>. In the desodiation process, the I<sub>D</sub>/I<sub>G</sub> ratio returns to 1.1, closing to the original value, which corresponds to the structure recovery. Notably, the D peaks remain nearly unchanged, while the G peak reversibly shifts during the discharge/charge process, which could be explained by the weakened stretching vibration of the in-plane C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/sbnd.gif" alt="single bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">C bonds due to the increased steric hindrance and electron density after Na<sup>+</sup> embedding. <em>Ex-situ</em> HRTEM images of all samples after the 5th insertion/extraction process are shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>. The layer spacing variation of NOHC-2 is the slightest among the three samples, which also proves that the larger spacing value contributes to structural stability and confirms the origin of the high-rate performance and cycling stability under high current density. The thinner NaF-rich SEI layer, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11</span></span></a><span>, could inhibit the <a href="/topics/materials-science/oxidation-reaction" title="Learn more about oxidation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">oxidation</a> of the electrolyte and the corrosion/solvent of the electrode and stabilize the electrode structure, which corresponding to the TEM images after 1000th sodiation/desodiation process (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12</span></span></a><span>). Based on the analyses of <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS), NOHC-2 electrodes have the lowest charge transfer impedance among the NOHCs, which indicates that it has the fastest ion diffusion kinetics (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S13</span></span></a>). Hence, the multi-merits of hierarchical porous structure, modest N/O dual-doping contents, and the largest layer spacing, contribute to enough active sites and outstanding Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion kinetics of NOHC-2, which could be advanced to practical applications for high power density devices.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0090">To further understand the Na<sup>+</sup><span> insertion behavior in NOHC-2, <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/dft-calculations" title="Learn more about DFT calculation from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">DFT calculation</a> is performed to calculate the energy cost of Na</span><sup>+</sup> insertion into carbon with interlayer distances of 3.4, 3.8, 4.0, and 4.2&nbsp;Ã… (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S14</span></span></a>). When the interlayer distance is 3.4&nbsp;Ã… (approximately the graphite), the energy cost is 0.68&nbsp;eV, which is not feasible for Na<sup>+</sup> insertion. But, when the interlayer distance increased to 3.8&nbsp;Ã…, the energy cost drastically decreased to âˆ’0.48&nbsp;eV, suggesting the Na<sup>+</sup> can be inserted into the interlayers. After further increasing the interlayer distance to over 4.2&nbsp;Ã…, the energy cost is below âˆ’1.18&nbsp;eV, indicating the Na<sup>+</sup> can intercalate into the interlayers more easily. In addition, we simulated the change in adsorption energy in the presence of C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O bonds. Adsorption energy for Na<sup>+</sup> in C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O doped graphene layers was âˆ’3.77&nbsp;eV, which shows that the presence of C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O is more conducive to the rapid adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup>. Besides, the carbonâ€“oxygen double bond (Î») in the C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O groups was 1.25&nbsp;Ã…, lower than that of 1.26&nbsp;Ã… after the simulated sodiation process. Those results indicate that the carbonâ€“oxygen double bond is broken and combined with Na during the sodiation process.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">To evaluate the potential of NOHC-2 anode in practical applications, full cells were assembled and characterized. Robust PB with good cyclic stability in sodium half cell was selected in this work as the cathode to match with NOHC-2 anode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S15</span></span></a>). In the assembled full cell, Na<sup>+</sup> normally migrates from the NOHC-2 anode to the PB cathode during the discharge process <strong>(</strong><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a><span>a), while the <a href="/topics/materials-science/electron-transfer" title="Learn more about electrons transfer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrons transfer</a> from the anode to the cathode in the external circuit, and vice versa. The charge/discharge curves of specific half and full cells in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>b indicate different Na<sup>+</sup> storage processes in the cathodes/anodes. Thus, a reversible charge capacity of 155.3&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at a current density of 100&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> could be obtained from the full cell (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>c) with a capacity retention of 82.3% after 100 cycles, demonstrating the great potential of NOHC-2 as anode candidate for ultrastable SIBs. From another aspect, the charge/discharge curves of the full cell remain consistent under different current densities as exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d, indicating desirable rate performances. Especially, the full cell delivers a competitive reversible capacity of 205.5&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and a reversible capacity of 196, 175, 128, and 74&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at the current densities of 30, 50, 100, and 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d, e), which bounces back to 205.5&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> when the current density returns to 20&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, demonstrating superior capacity recoverability. In addition, the PB//NOHC-2 full cell still exhibits good cycling stability even at a high current density of 2000&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, which can get the <a href="/topics/materials-science/led-lamp" title="Learn more about LED lamp from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">LED lamp</a> light up (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#s0025" name="bs0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="s0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S16</span></span></a><span>). Furthermore, the assembled PB//NOHC-2 full cell delivers a high <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-density" title="Learn more about energy density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy density</a> of 97.3&nbsp;Wh&nbsp;kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup> and a large power density of 985.7&nbsp;W&nbsp;kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, which are advantageous among the previously reported results (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0025" name="bf0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>f) <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0180" name="bb0180" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0180"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[36]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0265" name="bb0265" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0265"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0270" name="bb0270" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0270"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#b0275" name="bb0275" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="b0275"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0025"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr5.jpg" height="373" alt="" aria-describedby="cn0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (486KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (486KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S1385894723029686-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cn0025"><p id="sp0040"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. PB//NOHC-2 full cell characterization results. (a) Schematic of the discharge process; (b) Normalized charge/discharge profiles of the full battery compared with half cell, (c) Long-term cycle stability, (d) Charge/discharge curves, (e) Rate capability at different current densities from 20 to 500&nbsp;mA&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and (f) Ragone plot compared with the previously reported results.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0015"><h2 id="st040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">In summary, NOHCs with plentiful C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;"><span>O groups, hierarchical pore structure, and expanded interlayer were synthesized through a facile <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/pyrolysis" title="Learn more about pyrolysis process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pyrolysis process</a> assisted by NaCl hard template. The stable honeycomb morphology with hierarchical micropore structure alleviates the volume change of the Na</span><sup>+</sup> insertion/extraction into/from NOHC-2. The introduced active sites (mainly as C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O) increase the reversible capacity for NOHC-2 electrodes by forming C<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">O<img src="https://sdfestaticassets-us-east-1.sciencedirectassets.com/shared-assets/55/entities/dbnd6.gif" alt="6-point double bond" style="vertical-align: middle;">Na compounds with Na<sup>+</sup>, which is found highly reversible upon cycling. In addition, a high pyrrolic-N percentage in NOHC-2 is beneficial to enlarge carbon interlayer spacing, contributing to decreased energy barrier for Na<sup>+</sup> (de)intercalation process. Consequently, the NOHC-2 electrodes deliver a high reversible capacity of 324.3&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 300 cycles, and superior cycling stabilities over 15,000 cycles at high current densities (10.0&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>). Moreover, a full cell assembled by NOHC-2 anode and PB cathode presents excellent <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performances from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performances</a>, with outstanding energy/power densities (97.3&nbsp;Wh&nbsp;kg</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>/985.7&nbsp;W&nbsp;kg<sup>âˆ’1</sup>).
